title: Mining Exemplars for Object Recognition using Affinity Propagation

author: Edwin Hancock, Department of Computer Science, University of York

segmentation: This is joint work that I've been doing with Xinping jar and it aims to.
Try to learn class prototypes from large databases containing many different classes of objects.

So in prior work what xiangping jar and I have done is to try to develop a representation of images based on graphs and sift features and so the idea is that we take an image, we apply a SIFT detector to the image to extract a large number of SIFT features.
We extract the most salient of those using a saliency detection technique, and then we constructed along a graph.
Once we have those salient sift features to hand, the next step is to.
Attempt to match different images and compare their similarities and the novel aspect of our work is to propose a new similarity measure.
When we multiply the size of the maximum common subgraph by the exponential of the negative distance between the points in the image under alignment.
So that's our similarity measure and in the past we've attempted to cluster images together to find objects of the same class based on this similarity measure.
And a recursive self organizing map.

The novel aspect of this piece of work is that we have explored in addition to the previous processing steps, the use of Freeman's affinity propagation technique as a way of discovering class prototypes.

So Freeman's algorithm is described in a paper which appeared in nature awhile ago, and what we've shown here are the results of applying this affinity propagation method to our graph into our image similarity measure, and so the first set of examples here show a set of faces under different poses and expressions, and the affinity propagation method is able to extract class examples correctly for four different classes.
We then explored a much larger problem which involves a data images taken from the coil.

Google and our own datasets 55,000 in total, where we know what the classes of objects present are, and in the paper we give we give values based on the F measure which is a harmonic mean of the precision and recall and the method appears to work fairly effectively.
So thank you very much indeed.
